# intervalUnit

**Instance Property**

The amount of time – in calendar units such as day, month, or year – that represents a fraction of the total payment interval.

## Declaration

```swift
var intervalUnit: NSCalendar.Unit { get set }
```

## Discussion

The default value for the interval unit is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSCalendar/Unit/month].

The supported [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Foundation/NSCalendar/Unit] interval units are:

- [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/CoreFoundation/CFCalendarUnit/minute]
- [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/CoreFoundation/CFCalendarUnit/hour]
- [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/CoreFoundation/CFCalendarUnit/day]
- [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/CoreFoundation/CFCalendarUnit/month]
- [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/CoreFoundation/CFCalendarUnit/year]

To set an interval unit based on a week, set [doc://com.apple.passkit/documentation/PassKit/PKRecurringPaymentSummaryItem/intervalUnit] to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/CoreFoundation/CFCalendarUnit/day], and set [doc://com.apple.passkit/documentation/PassKit/PKRecurringPaymentSummaryItem/intervalCount] to a multiple of the number of days per week. To find the number of days for a week in the current calendar, call `NSCalendar.current.maximumRange(of: .weekday)!.count)`.

For example, the code below sets a payment that occurs every two weeks.

```swift
let daysPerWeek = NSCalendar.current.maximumRange(of: .weekday)!.count)

intervalUnit = .day
intervalCount = daysPerWeek * 2
```

## Setting the payment interval

- **intervalCount**: The number of interval units that make up the total payment interval.
